justification: The article states that the St. Petersburg paradox results "can be captured by assuming maximization of [a] concave subjective utility function that implies risk aversion," linking the construct to this specific model parameter as its measure.

It notes that prospect theory "modifies EUT by adding 'probability weighting' parameters to capture" the experiment where participants over-react to very low probabilities, directly tying the construct to those parameters.
The text explains that prospect theory adds a "'loss aversion' parameter to capture" choices reflecting an oversensitivity to losses, identifying that parameter as the measure of the construct.
